Broken Age
A family friendly, hand-animated, puzzle-filled adventure game with an all-star cast, including Elijah Wood, Jack Black and Masasa Moyo. Funded by a record breaking crowdfunding campaign and designed by industry legend Tim Schafer, Broken Age is a timeless coming-of-age story.

July 14

Broken Age is now available with Russian Subtitles!

A while ago we announced that we were working on a Russian translation of Broken Age for the Windows, OSX and Linux versions of the game.

We’re happy to tell you that those translations, both the subtitles and in-game textures, are live right now on Steam!

Спасибо, и наслаждайтесь игрой

9.5 – IGN

9 – Polygon

9.5 – Destructoid

About This Game

Broken Age is a family friendly, hand-animated, puzzle-filled adventure game with an all-star cast, including Elijah Wood, Jack Black and Masasa Moyo. Funded by a record breaking crowdfunding campaign and designed by industry legend Tim Schafer, Broken Age is a timeless coming-of-age story of barfing trees and talking spoons.

Vella Tartine and Shay Volta are two teenagers in strangely similar situations, but radically different worlds. The player can freely switch between their stories, helping them take control of their own lives, and dealing with the unexpected adventures that follow.

Starring:

Elijah Wood as Shay
Masasa Moyo as Vella
Jack Black as Harm'ny Lightbeard
Jennifer Hale as Mom
Wil Wheaton as Curtis
Pendleton Ward as Gus
READ MORE

ulfben
235 products in account
12 reviews
Not Recommended
13.2 hrs on record
Posted: May 9
After finishing (the incredibly frustrating) Act 2 of Broken Fine Adventure, the only thing I want is to watch the development documentary. Judging my the severe lack of content and polish in the second half, I assume every other minute of the documentary is going to be filled with cocaine and hookers - nothing else would explain how they went so far over budget, and so far over time.

The puzzles in Act 2 are obtuse, backtrack-heavy, trial-and-error ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. To make matters worse, they're frequently re-used. Tedious timing puzzles that provides no feedback whatsoever will keep you occupied with retry after long-winding-retry. And if those don't make you pull your hair out, you'll probably go insane scouring the world for the next puzzle - as several scenes are confusing as to what exits are available! Unless you remember the layouts of the first game you're probably going to get stuck simply for not having any apparent way to go.

I wanted to buy the game for some non-gamer friends- and family. I want to share the art style, humor and characters, and the low skill requirement of a point-&-click adventure makes it perfect. But yeah, no. I can just imagine how frustrated real people would be trying, having to struggle with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ logic if Act 2.

Act 2 is so incredibly poor that the game would have been better left unfinished, I ♥♥♥♥ you not.

Luna
669 products in account
4 reviews
Not Recommended
14.8 hrs on record
Posted: May 9
I kickstarted Broken Age back when it was called Double Fine Adventure, and comming in my expectation was to get something that played as well as the Lucas Arts games of old, with large worlds to explore, a lot of things to interact with, and puzzles that make me feel proud about figuring them out (or stupid for not doing so when I finally get it).

When I got to play the first episode the first thing i reacted to was the art style. The game really has a picture book for kids vibe that continues through the entire game. If you can stand it, the graphics are pretty, and the animations are smooth. I thought the game was over all pretty, but it's up to your taste if you can stand it.

The voices are also well done. All character have well sounding voices, and what little dialogue there is is mostly well written, and some characters are memorable and likable. What little plot there is is interesting, and in the end I must concede that Double Fine managed to create an interesting world I would like to return to in what will hopefully be a Broken Age 2.

All that said, why is this a negative review? Well, the game has very little content when it comes to gameplay.
Over all there are very few objects you can carry around, and mostly it is fairly obvious what they are supposed to be used for. This means that the item based puzzles are trivial to solve.

Act 1 mostly consists of moving around in the cloud kingdom and a fishing village for Vella, and a space ship for Shay. The puzzles are mostly embarassingly easy fetch quests, and to be fair, act 1 might make a good introduction to adventure games for a young child. Act 1 ends with a plot twist I enjoyed, and after it I was looking forward to the meat of the game that I thought would be act 2.

Act 2 mostly consists of moving around in the cloud kingdom and fishing village as Shay, and a space ship for Vella.
The puzzles are still mostly embarassingly easy fetch quests, there are a few mildly tricky puzzles, and then there are a few puzzles that are just a big slap in the face where the solution is only obvious after you have solved it, or only available to the other character as something they might comment on or see in the background.

The end game mostly centers around wiring up robots with patterns only the other character can find, and the ending really didn't feel very satisfactory to me, but it does leave room for a sequel which I hope we will get to see.

The main problem with act 2 is that it doesn't really expand on act 1. The characters are still stuck in the same small world with only a few items and the same characters as in act 1 available to them to use at any time, and ultimately that leaves the puzzles no more interesting than the ones in the introduction that is act 1. Ultimately I have to ask: What took so long? After years of development I was expecting a lot more gameplay content than this.

Broken age is not a bad game, but it is not a very good one either. I'd give it a neutral grade if I could. I don't hate it, but why waste time on it when you could be playing something better?
Read More

buddy
342 products in account
11 reviews
Not Recommended
11.7 hrs on record
Posted: June 2
The puzzles in the first half of the game are too simplistic and easy, and the puzzles in the second half are arbitrary and absurd. There needed to be some middle ground, but there wasn't.
You may say that Adventure Games have always been that way, but I'd disagree. The best LucasArts and Sierra adventure games always had challenging puzzles that could be solved logically. In Broken Age I felt like I was just clicking on random things until something worked.
The bottom of the line is, this is not the "Classic style adventure game" it was promised to be. If you want a GOOD adventure game I recommend getting something from Amanita Design or Daedalic Entertainment. They're the ones actually making games that feel like the glory days of LucasArts adventure games.

I loved Act 1, but Act 2 really fell flat. Confusing puzzles and an underwhelming story. It feels like Double Fine spent too much time on creating a beautiful looking game, and not enough time on story and gameplay mechanics. What a let down.

2 reviews
Not Recommended
15.0 hrs on record
Posted: May 10
Awful mess. Just awful.

I wish I could praise this game I really do. It's just not possible. I even held out judgement until the second act was released.

I could argue for the antiquated mechanics but still it's that one puzzle whe Shea needs to program a robot, and the robot's programming uses shapes seen all across his own ship. So as vella you explore his ship for some kind of robot programming clue and nothing. Then once you spend 2 hours and give up and cheat do they say "Oh on the blackboard of the picture with Shae with his mom is a small image of the pattern you need" That alone made this a terrible experience because that is the second of Shae's puzzles and the rest of his are in the same vein where they simply expect you to just figure these things out through complete nonsense backwards logic.

I don't mind fetch quests, and having to try multiple times, and even having to pay attention to obscure clues. (One of my favorite games is Myst.) But if you're going to decide that the player now needs to keep a collection of screenshots half a gig large just to solve your games puzzles then ef you. You don't deserve to make games. That is too much useless work and my comp notebook of Riven notes agrees too.
